basketball.context: Breaking the press with foundation blocks

phase1.name: Sports Language (Block Coding)
phase1.description: Learn sequences using basketball terminology. Visual block interface: START → BLOCK_1_POUND → BLOCK_1_POUND → ADVANCE
phase1.learningObjective: Students understand that code is step-by-step instructions

phase2.name: Transition Bridge
phase2.description: See how sports language maps to code concepts. Side-by-side view: Block sequence | Python code
phase2.example:
Block: START → BLOCK_1_POUND
Code: start()
pound_dribble()
advance()

phase3.name: Python Learning
phase3.description: Write Python code for sequences. Create step-by-step programs
phase3.example:
def break_press():
    start()
    pound_dribble()
    pound_dribble()
    pound_dribble()
    advance()

learningObjectives: Understand that code is step-by-step instructions
See connection between blocks and Python code

returnFlow.onComplete: Return to Book 1 page with success status

card.title: The Foundation Block
card.description: Learn sequences through breaking the press with foundation blocks

progression.nextBookReason: After mastering sequences, students learn conditionals (if/then decisions) which build on sequential thinking
progression.conceptProgression: Sequences → Conditionals (decision-making builds on step-by-step thinking)

phase1.name: Sports Language (Block Coding)
phase1.description: Learn conditionals using basketball terminology. Visual block interface: IF [defender goes left] THEN [crossover right]
phase1.example: IF [defender goes left] THEN [crossover right] ELSE [go straight]
phase1.learningObjective: Students understand that conditionals make decisions

phase2.name: Transition Bridge
phase2.description: See how conditional blocks map to Python code. Side-by-side view: Block conditional | Python if statement
phase2.example:
Block: IF [defender goes left] THEN [crossover right]
Code: if defender_goes_left:
    crossover_right()
phase2.learningObjective: Students understand that conditional blocks = Python if statements

phase3.name: Python Learning
phase3.description: Write Python if statements. Create decision-making programs

learningObjectives: See connection between blocks and Python if statements

returnFlow.onComplete: Return to Book 2 page with success status

card.title: The Code of Flow
card.description: Learn conditionals through creating space with crossover dribbles

progression.nextBookReason: After mastering conditionals, students learn loops (repetition) which combine sequences and conditionals

basketball.context: Creating patterns and breaking them at the right moment

phase1.name: Sports Language (Block Coding)
phase1.description: Learn loops using basketball terminology. Visual block interface: REPEAT [fake left] 3 TIMES, THEN [go right]
phase1.example:
REPEAT [Block 3: Fake Left] 3 TIMES
THEN [Block 3: Go Right]
phase1.learningObjective: Students understand that loops repeat patterns

phase2.name: Transition Bridge
phase2.description: See how loop blocks map to Python code. Side-by-side view: Block loop | Python for loop
phase2.example:
Block: REPEAT [fake left] 3 TIMES
Code: for i in range(3):
    fake_left()
phase2.learningObjective: Students understand that loop blocks = Python for loops

phase3.name: Python Learning
phase3.description: Write Python for loops. Use range() to control repetitions. Create loop patterns in code
phase3.example:
for i in range(3):
    fake_left()
    print(f'Fake {i+1}')

go_right()
print('Pattern broken!')
phase3.learningObjective: Students can write Python for loops with range()

learningObjectives: See connection between blocks and Python for loops
Write Python for loops with range()

returnFlow.onComplete: Return to Book 3 page with success status

card.title: The Pattern
card.description: Learn loops through creating and breaking patterns with in & out dribbles

progression.nextBookReason: After mastering loops, students learn functions (combining sequences, conditionals, and loops)
progression.conceptProgression: Loops → Functions (combining concepts into reusable blocks)

phases.phase1: Sports Language (Block Coding) - Students learn concepts using basketball terminology and visual blocks
phases.phase2: Transition Bridge - Students see blocks → Python code connection
phases.phase3: Python Learning - Students write actual Python code

3-5.pythonExposure: See Python code examples, understand concepts, not required to write

6-8.pythonExposure: Write basic for loops, understand range() syntax
